text: in this video you'll see how to evaluate
third-party resources with AWS config
with AWS config you can create rules to
audit configurations of third-party
resources to verify compliance with your
organization's policies and guidelines
let's navigate to AWS config to get
started
AWS config is a service that enables you
to assess audit and evaluate the
configurations of your resources now you
can perform configuration audit and
compliance verification for third-party
resources such as github repositories
Microsoft Active Directory resources or
any on-premises server just like you do
for AWS resources
as an example we'll review a custom
solution that will monitor a github
account to ensure the repositories are
private first let's check the privacy
status of two repositories and github
we can see that both repositories are
set to private next let's view the
private github resource type in AWS
cloud formation
public resource providers are those
provided by AWS to manage specific AWS
service resources private resource
providers are those resource providers
that you have explicitly registered for
use in your AWS account
these may be resource providers you've
created yourself as well as ones shared
with you in this case we only want to
see the private resources in the cloud
formation registry
by registering a third-party resource
and cloud formation you can validate
data against a defined resource schema
to ensure it is compliant and consistent
this resource type defines the schema
for a github repository next let's
navigate to AWS lambda to view the
lambda functions that retrieve and
validate data and evaluate compliance of
our resources
first let's view the details of the
github connector function which connects
github and AWS config
a cloud watch event triggers this
function to execute on a predefined
schedule this function retrieves the
repository configuration from github
transforms it to match the registered
schema and sends it to AWS config notice
that the code references the cloud
formation resource type we saw earlier
the code also retrieves the github
access token from AWS secrets manager
next let's verify that the identity and
access management or iam execution rule
used by this function provides the
necessary permissions
the basic policy provides standard lamda
execution permissions and the custom
policy provides additional permissions
let's view the details of the custom
policy
the custom policy provides permissions
to read the github access keys stored an
AWS secrets manager to get the schema
version for the resource and AWS
CloudFormation and to update and delete
resource configurations in AWS config
together the basic and custom policies
provide the I am execution role with the
appropriate permissions now let's return
to AWS lambda2 review the other function
the github repository private rural
function evaluates whether a github
repository is compliant with a config
rule let's copy the Amazon resource name
or a RN for this function because we'll
need it later to create an AWS configure
rule that references this function
here we can see that this function
designates private repositories as
compliant and public repositories as non
compliant now let's view resources
imported into AWS config using these
functions
on the resources screen you can see that
a new category is now available to
filter resources on these resources were
imported into AWS config using the
github connector lambda function we
looked at earlier
let's filter the resource category to
sample org
let's take a look at the details for the
first resource that was discovered
the resource timeline shows changes to
resource configuration and compliance
over time
you can also review all the
configuration details for this
repository that were imported from
github
now let's create a new AWS config rule
to evaluate whether these repositories
are private
the first step is to specify the rule
type in this case we'll create a custom
rule
the second step is to configure the rule
name and description for the rule
next we'll paste the AR n we copied
earlier for the lambda function that
evaluates compliance
AWS config evaluates resources based on
a trigger will specify the trigger as a
change to the resource configuration
next we'll specify the third-party
resource for this rule
the third step is to review the
configurations and add the rule
after we refresh the screen the rule
shows as compliant because both github
repositories are private so that we can
test this further let's return to github
and make one of the repositories public
let's acknowledge the warning to make
this repository public
now let's return to AWS config to
re-evaluate if the resource
configuration complies with our rule
after a few minutes we can refresh the
page to see the updated results
we can see the rule now shows as
non-compliant let's look at the rule
details to check the compliance for each
resource
as expected the rule identified the
repository set to public as a
non-compliant resource
you've just seen how to evaluate
third-party resources with AWS config
